displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: which will see where it is. So we put a little radioactive tag- Patient: Okay. Doctor: and the only PSMA does is go from the surface inside the cancer cell, and it’s almost, it’s almost a way to build something up inside. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we can get a really nice picture. Well, the next easy lead from there is why not put something that’s a killer mode. Uh what they’ve seen, and what’s been published in the German, mostly Germany, it’s relatively nontoxic. Uh the big toxicity has been uh the salivary glands seem to make PSMA also. So some people end up with dry mouth uh as a side effect. Uh the kidney also makes P- PSMA. They haven’t really reported acute kidney damage, hasn’t really been a big issue, but they haven’t really followed the people long enough I think to know- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know, if down the road if there are kidney problems. At least what they’ve reported so far they don’t - they don’t see it. Patient: I see. Doctor: So I would say the procedure, I normally do it on the trials, but I had this experience with the guys in Germany. What they do is they bring you there and they scan you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: With the imaging part. They see how active is your cancer. How much of the stuff is there on PSMA.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. We definitely have a program to help city residents if they have trouble getting in that often. Huh, huh, you know, the chemotherapy is going to cause hair loss. Huh, seventy-five percent of the time you lose your hair, it grows back. Huh, you might get excess tearing because it can block the tear ducts. So a little bit. The other reason why we might want to wait a little bit is just to see how much your palsy is going to get better. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, huh, it drops blood counts. So right now your white count’s good. Your platelets are good. Huh, but we may need to give you a blood transfusion if we make you more anemic. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, huh, we can drop your blood count, white count, and so you might get a higher risk of infection. Huh, usually we know about that. We tell you to be careful. Sometimes we give you antibiotics. And if it happens every time, sometimes we’re going to give you a medicine that’s going to bring up your white count so it doesn’t drop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Typically, we don’t use that medicine unless it drops. Huh, over the long haul, you might get, huh, injury to the longest nerves in your body. Those are your fingertips and to your toes. Huh, you get numbness. Huh, so we try to go out as many as ten cycles. Most people notice it by the sixth or seventh. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But I’m going to ask you every time can you zip up your thing? Can you button your pants? Can you button your shirt? If you tell me I can’t, I’m going to stop. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: But if your shirt’s coming in and it’s unbuttoned, even though you tell me you did, I’m not going to believe you. Okay? I have ways to check. Patient: Right. (Laughs)

Patient: Okay. The pills that you told me to stop taking, should I go back on them? Doctor: No. You should not. You’re done. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We’re going to try a new drug, huh, that’s quite expensive, and we have to just be able to figure out if we can get it for you. Patient: Okay. Family Member: I appreciate it. Right. Patient: And how would I find out? Family Member 1: You do nothing. Family Member: You do nothing. They’ll call you. Patient: Oh, you’ll call me? Doctor: I’m not going to call you. The pharmacy will call you. Patient: The pharmacy, right. Family Member: Pharmacy. Right.

Patient: Was that Dr. Y or W? Family Member: I don’t know. Wayne maybe. I don’t know. Patient: Somebody made a comment that… Doctor: I think you know so all the studies, they try to go up to ten. They try to go up to ten. So we just try to chunk – you’re a little off cycle because you know we started off with the vitamin C thing so three more and then… Family Member: Seriously, we need three more? Doctor: Yeah. We want ten total. Patient: So you’re… Family Member: She’s serious. Doctor: No I am, I’m serious. Patient: Wake up, wake up, five more? Doctor: Yeah, total over time, but let’s just do one at a time. Patient: Oh.

Family Member: Um hum. DOC - then the best way to do that although it’s still not a cure is hormone therapy plus or minus something else. So something new. Doctor: Right, so there’s no question that hormone therapy within the first three months is going to kill like ninety-nine percent of the cancer. Happens with almost everyone. With radiotherapy you know there’s a decent chance that it’s going to kill whatever cancer happens to be part that we radiate – Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: - but the rest of the cancer which is going to be invisible is obviously going to be outside of that radiation field. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: It’s not going to be touched. And the concern with that is although I am a proponent of someone that wants to – If your goal is absolutely to avoid hormone therapy as long as possible, that’s a good option for you. And again, what would be driving that would be more quality of life. Patient: And that’s the um I guess that’s what’s (pause3secs) Healthcare Professional: Right, you just want to do what you have to, yes, exactly. No, we get that. Patient: Because I know there are so many side effects. Healthcare Professional: Right. Patient: So if where where the - we’re looking is probably radiation and sort of like not a complete hormone but like some sort of and I’m probably going to get some sort of a modified sense of a hormonal thing. So I’ll still have some effects of it, but in that effect so that the radiation if we do that part when we target it on what we know where it’s landed, the hormonal will be sort of be keeping everything else at bay at this point. Healthcare Professional: Right.

Patient: Oh. Doctor: We made a deal with one of the drug companies who makes the immune therapy. Family Member: Well, they are good for something. Doctor: So, my advice right now, we don’t do anything. You’re responding to hormone treatment. Let’s keep going. And, at some point, we don’t know if this has anything to do with BRCA2 or whatever, but at some point, you’re going to become resistant. Everybody does. And, at that point, we, we will discuss what to do next. And, normally, Patient: So --- Doctor: What to do next – I’m sorry – is to give you another hormone therapy. But, in your case, what, what we might do next is consider like, a trial where we use one of these DNA repair blockers. Um. And, we have two of them open right now that you would be eligible for. So. So, you know, the issue with you is I don’t want to talk about those yet because you might respond to hormone therapy for five more years. (laughs) Patient: Yeah. It, it was two hundred and fifty dollars. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Two hundred and— Family Member: It’s okay. We got to test twenty people. We’ll take the reduced price. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Well. If, but, if there isn’t – Family Member: Oh, we’re still going to do it

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So again, you’ve got the multiple sites of cancer in your bones, and you’ve got swollen glands down in your pelvis, don’t look like they’re from your cancer. Huh, let me see what I told you last time so that I am consistent. Okay. So what questions do you have for me? Patient: Huh, only one, I mean, huh, what are we going to do about this pain I’m feeling? Are we going to do what we’re doing? What we’ve been doing? Doctor: Yeah. I, I’m, I’m thinking we need to change. Huh, you know, get you off these pills and maybe go to chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Huh, chemotherapy’s got about a one in two chance of helping the pain. Huh, we could always radiate your bones if the pain doesn’t get better with the chemo. Huh, but I’d like to give you something that goes everywhere the cancer cells are, huh, so that, huh, huh, it’s a different approach than what we’ve done. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Huh, so normally what you would end up doing is stopping the four pills. You can stop that. The prednisone you would stay on because we need it for the chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I think last time we talked a little bit about we have one clinical trial where we are giving men chemotherapy. Huh, that’s the standard. Huh, and then we, huh, ask men to participate and also getting vitamin C. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That’s the experimental part. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay, so obviously radiation we’re going to do, we’re going to do. In terms of the thought process on the chemo – what’s the – as soon as we’re ready to say yes? Doctor: Just let us know. Patient: Okay. It won’t take long; I just want to absorb everything. Then I get back. Okay. Doctor: Um, R___ do you have any other questions? Family Member 1: Just the sequence of things. The hormone therapy and the chemo therapy and Zytiga. Are they all started at the same time? Doctor: Uh, pretty much, yeah. Um and we could start the hormone shot any time. Patient: I’m scheduled. Family Member: He’s scheduled today. Doctor: Oh you’re scheduled today, yes. Patient: One o’clock. Doctor: So you’ll get that today but we generally start the, we have to put in for the Zytiga to get approved; we have to put in the chemo to get approved. It takes a couple of weeks to do all that. So we would start all of that sort of in you know mid-January. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay.

Family Member: Right right. Doctor: But so if what I'm saying doesn't make sense or if I'm using terms that are not familiar to you, please just stop me and and just say what do you mean by that? Or that we haven't heard that before. Family Member: You’re very thorough. You can tell you’re a teacher. Doctor: Both of my parents are teachers. So they’ll be happy to hear that. Doctor: All right, okay, those that's your classwork from this session today, okay? All right. So let me go make a copy of this so that you have this for your records in the answers and get that blood drawn. And then I'll contact the research nurses and let them know that. Okay, all right. I'll be right back.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Family Member: And so as a layperson, that’s all we have. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s, that’s the only way when he gets his blood test and it comes back and, you know, you said, oh, gosh, the PSA has risen again. You know? That’s our only frame of reference as to where we are in all this and what the cancer is doing. Doctor: There’s no question that we would have preferred it would have dropped. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But the absence of a drop does not necessarily mean the drug hasn’t worked. It, it might mean that the drug has not worked as well as we had hoped or anticipated, uh, but it might still be doing something, or it might take longer to work. To start working the drug may have to build up in your system. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Or in your case, you haven’t really been on a full dose, and you’ve had these interruptions where you’ve been, you know, totally off of it for three weeks, you know? And now for another two weeks. So. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: So when he comes back on September fifth, the two-hundred milligrams will be here, so he can take it with him that day? Doctor: Yes. That’s the plan. Provided that the hemoglobin is sufficient. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: Right. Okay. So then if the hemoglobin is not sufficient when he comes back, for example, he gets the transfusion, he gets here, and do the lab or something, so if it’s not, then what happens?

Family Member: Right. Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: So per the protocol. Um, we have him come back in twenty-eight days, a month. I don’t know, I mean you probably won’t make a decision before that but we’ll have you come in on the twentieth. Patient: We will definitely have some idea though (chuckles) Healthcare Professional: Yeah, just as a follow-up off study to see how you’re feeling and everything off the drug, get another PSA um kinda see where things are. And um, I’ll let you guys finish up. Doctor: Well we need to have like a close-out visit and come up with the end-of-study visit, which is a Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah and so we’ll be looking to do that anyway. But I agree with you. We should make that decision you know before then. Patient: We will. I will talk to my wife. As a matter of fact when we leave here I’m going to head to the rehab. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And the four of us can kind of you know talk. But I think that’s the direction that we’ll probably go- Doctor: Once you have a clearer picture of you know which way you want to go, whether it’s radiotherapy with hormones for now or hormones plus or minus some secondary therapy which may work better, then I would also like to talk to you about some of the clinical trials in each of those categories. Since they are mutually exclusive right now. It’s kind of either like a radiotherapy based trial or hormone therapy plus something new. So once -

Patient: Yeah. That’s a good point. Right. Doctor: Yeah. I mean, I think if you want to explore that, my feeling would be if you can get it on the study, well and good. If not, you should explore if you can go and, you know, I don’t know what it costs there, and, you know, what you have to pay. Family Member: If you can get on, on the study, which would involve the scan, doing the scan? Doctor: Doing the scan first. Family Member: Yeah. Of course. Doctor: But even there, they would do the scan first, because if it’s not going to help you, they’re not going to push you to get the treatment that’s not going to work. Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: And that’s one treatment every-? Doctor: Six weeks. Patient: Six weeks? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: For-?

Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: In case. Now, it wasn’t like you went all the way down zero and stayed there. So you were always around a one to two. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know? You’re in the fours a couple of times now, so. Patient: Um hum. Could it be because I’ll be in the sun a lot? Doctor: No. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Not that. You’re doing everything right. You are. Doctor: Everything from the music to showing up when you’re supposed to. You’re doing all the right things. Patient: Hum. Doctor: You really are. It’s just that the cancer doesn’t care. Patient: I get it.

Patient: Yep. Doctor: And let me see if you’re all set for when your next hormone shot is. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: So that’s due the last week of, first week of, last week of April. And you’re set for that. You already have that appointment set up, add on because it will be three weeks from now about when we might get started with the chemo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? I refilled the ibuprofen. I sent it to your local pharmacy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so you’re set there. And there’s probably nobody out there right now. Patient: Right. Doctor: I always end up with you late in the day. Doctor: At least you don’t have to go to the ER tonight. Patient: Right. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? So then I’ll let you head out and, huh, we’ll check on whether the trial makes sense. So I’ll say, read the consents, we will review your records to see if eligible, because if you need blood, I can give you a blood transfusion, but the hep C we may not be able to.

Family Member: That’s okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So um I think we should take it one step at a time and keep all our options open. So uh stay with the Xtandi and the Lupron and bring in the BET. And uh I I’m gonna be getting it from Midtown rather from here and they’ll know that? Doctor: Oh well once – what I was going to propose is that I give you the copy of the consent. If you want you can read it and uh if you’re ready to sign today you can, or we can schedule all the testing in anticipation of putting you on the study and all of that downtown and then that same day you can come in and sign the consent and do all the testing necessary. That gives you some time to think it over talk it over before signing. Patient: And you said it would just be a couple days I’d have to be there? Doctor: The two days are the long days. There are other days that you would be coming in and I just… Patient: For how long? Doctor: Well that’s what the consent will give you the exact details Patient: Okay, Yeah. Doctor: of how many times a week, but the first few weeks typically are very, what this is called is a Phase I study. So it’s an earlier setting like I said the combination really we don’t have a good handle on what to expect in terms of toxicities, what dose, etc. So one of the side effects that has been noted so far is that the platelets can drop with this medication. So that is something of course the blood counts will be monitored anyway. Besides that kidney function, liver function, all that will also be monitored and checked. You go – undergo EKG monitoring that will be hard test like and echo before you start. So there is a lot of components. One additional component is that you probably will need to do a biopsy again as part of the study. Doctor: So that’s something to think about before you say yes or no. Patient: And does platelets dropping how would that affect me physically? Doctor: Well if it gets really low then it can cause bleeding and things like that -
